text:
Are the international users using client systems also domain joined machines?
And joined to the same domain? 
Also, are the international users connecting via a VPN connection or thru a
Terminal Services Gateway? The RDP client has an option to TSG option to bypass
“local addresses” which makes the RDS client use the TSG instead of the direct
VPN connection. 
There are several Windows Event logs specific to RDS/Terminal Services that log
events that can be useful in debugging these kinds of issues. They are under the
Application And Services Logs\Microsoft\Windows\TerminalServices-NNNN and
RemoteApp-NNNN nodes

metadata.subject: RE: [patchmanagement] Re: RDP NLA Issue
metadata.email_text_original:
You don't often get email from nick.palmer@kcicorp.com. Learn why this is
important [https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification] 
Are the international users using client systems also domain joined machines?
And joined to the same domain? 
Also, are the international users connecting via a VPN connection or thru a
Terminal Services Gateway?  The RDP client has an option to TSG option to bypass
“local addresses” which makes the RDS client use the TSG instead of the direct
VPN connection. 
There are several Windows Event logs specific to RDS/Terminal Services that log
events that can be useful in debugging these kinds of issues. They are under the
Application And Services Logs\Microsoft\Windows\TerminalServices-NNNN and
RemoteApp-NNNN nodes 
From: 'Brown, Jeff' via PatchManagement <patchmanagement@googlegroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, February 01, 2024 7:28 AM
To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com
Subject: RE: [patchmanagement] Re: RDP NLA Issue 
Guess I am looking for some troubleshooting suggestions. 
The machines are up-to-date on MS patches, but this has been occurring since at
least December.
Link: https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/patchmanagement/PH7PR12MB6667561037B2A67A3A9B9537FC432%40PH7PR12MB6667.namprd12.prod.outlook.com
